JUDGES: András Sajó;Françoise Tulkens;Ireneu Cabral Barreto;Nona Tsotsoria;Vladimiro Zagrebelsky
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE .
CARDINAL . The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE the applicant married Mr PERSON . According to birth certificate no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL Mr PERSON was entitled to bear the CARDINAL above - mentioned forenames from the very moment of his birth . Her husband signed the marriage certificate as “ PERSON ” . The applicant chose to bear her husband ’s name by putting the suffix “ -né ” referring to the marriage ( házasságra utaló toldás ) after the first given name ( PERSON ) of her husband . In accordance with the widespread custom in GPE , the latter only used his first given name even in official contexts . The applicant ’s married name was registered as PERSON on the marriage certificate .

CARDINAL . The official before whom the marriage took place did not observe that the name chosen was against the law since , at the material time , a woman could only choose to bear the whole name of her husband , including all the given names . In the present case , the applicant ’s correct married name should have been PERSON .

CARDINAL . The mistake was not revealed in DATE when identity cards were introduced in GPE . The applicant ’s renewed identity card issued in DATE also contained the name PERSON . The applicant used this name in all official and private business . In particular , her social security card and tax identification certificate were issued in the name ORG .

CARDINAL . In DATE GPE introduced electronic data recording . In the new ORG ( PERSON ) the applicant ’s name was automatically entered in the manner prescribed by law , as PERSON . However , she did not receive any official notification of this fact . In DATE she and her husband were entered on the electoral register ( választói névjegyzék ) under the names PERSON and PERSON . This database relied on the general ORG .
CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant ’s husband died . The applicant then used the name PERSON with the prefix “ özv . ” indicating that she was a widow .

CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant lost her identity card . Based on ORG , ORG issued a new card which indicated her name as the widow of PERSON ( özv . PERSON ) . On CARDINAL DATE the applicant obtained an official certificate containing this name . The certificate ’s only function was to enable her to access her bank account since her new identity card contained a name that was different from the one she had used when opening the account . The text of the certificate expressly stated that it had been issued for CARDINAL - time use .

CARDINAL . The applicant lodged a complaint with ORG , seeking permission to bear the name PERSON . In DATE the Ministry informed her that , since her husband ’s official name was PERSON , she was entitled and obliged to bear that name in its entirety as a widow , and that it was not possible to change it to another form . Her name is at present registered as PERSON .

“ ( CARDINAL ) As a general rule , women should be entered in the registry under their family name ( birth name ) and forename . Exceptions , having to bear their husbands’ as well as their own family name and forename :
“ ( CARDINAL ) After the marriage , the wife shall bear
a ) her whole maiden name , or
b ) the whole name of her husband with the suffix referring to the marriage , to which she may attach her whole maiden name , or
c ) her husband ’s family name with the suffix referring to the marriage , to which she attaches her whole name , or
d ) her husband ’s family name to which she attaches her first name . ... ”
“ ( CARDINAL ) A person bearing his / her spouse ’s name can not alter it by way of a name - change ( névváltoztatás ) . ”
